title: 103_hr2396
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. Depository institutions can disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the information for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Individuals can sue a state for damages if their financial records are disclosed unlawfully by a state officer or employee. In cases of unauthorized disclosure of financial records by a state officer or employee, individuals can sue the state for damages in a US district court. No liability exists for good faith misinterpretations. Damages awarded in such cases include $1,000 per unauthorized disclosure or actual damages sustained by the plaintiff, plus additional amounts for willful disclosures. The term "depository institution" includes banks, credit unions, and affiliated parties. "Financial record" is defined by the Right to Financial Privacy Act. "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a state agency managing child support programs. A State child support enforcement agency administers programs for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies have access to and can use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer, and the agency provides written notice and certification to the consumer reporting agency. The term 'State child support enforcement agency' is defined as a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders as mandated by amendments to the Social Security Act. It outlines procedures for ensuring coverage of health care costs for children in child support orders issued or modified by state courts or administrative agencies. Additionally, it requires expedited handling of noncompliance allegations regarding health care coverage obligations. The Social Security Act mandates that states establish guidelines for health care coverage in child support orders. The Secretary will set minimum standards for these guidelines, including responsibilities for covering health care costs for children. The Secretary will establish guidelines for health care coverage in child support orders, including insurance provision, claims payment, rights to insurance information, coverage denial circumstances, penalties for non-compliance, and consideration of changes in parents' circumstances. The State must prioritize the child's best interests and parents' financial circumstances when developing these standards. The Secretary will issue regulations within 9 months and final regulations within 14 months to implement the amendments made by this subsection. Additionally, dependent health insurance provided due to successful enforcement will be included in the Incentive Payments Program under the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months to implement the enforcement of support orders requiring absent parents to obtain health insurance for children. Additionally, a study will be conducted to determine the impact of this provision. Services will conduct a study to determine incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report the study results to relevant committees within 12 months. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH CHILD SUPPORT ASSISTANCE TIME LIMITS. Amends the Social Security Act to include compliance standards for states. SEC. 6. EMPLOYERS MUST WITHHOLD WAGES FOR CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS WITHIN 10 DAYS; PENALTY FOR LATE PAYMENTS. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to withhold wages for child support payments within 10 days. Employers failing to do so will face a $1,000 penalty to be paid to the State. Penalties collected must be used for the State plan approved under section 454. Effective immediately upon enactment, applicable to wages paid thereafter. The Social Security Act requires states to comply with new requirements for their plans under section 454. States with 2-year legislative sessions have flexibility in meeting these requirements. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing States to locate absent parents for child support obligations and visitation enforcement by accessing records from other States and Federal sources. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing States to locate absent parents for child support and visitation enforcement. The network allows for both online and batch processing of locate requests, with a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for information to be broadcast and returned to a requesting State. Access to court information is facilitated by locating a computer terminal in each court. HR 2396 IH----2 proposes expanding the Parent Locator Service into a national network for locating absent parents for child support and visitation enforcement. The network allows for online and batch processing of locate requests with a 48-hour turnaround time. Access to court information is facilitated by placing a computer terminal in each court.
